epidemiology: Affects ~69 million people globally each year. Most common in young adults and elderly. Major causes: road traffic accidents, falls, assaults.
treatment_protocol: Stabilize airway, breathing, circulation → CT imaging → Surgical or conservative management

epidemiology: More common in elderly and alcoholics. Incidence increases with age. Can be acute, subacute, or chronic.
treatment_protocol: Identify via CT → Burr hole/craniotomy → Neuro ICU monitoring

epidemiology: Second most common type of stroke (~10–15% of all strokes). Incidence increases with hypertension and age.
treatment_protocol: Emergency CT → Stabilization → Neurosurgical consultation

epidemiology: Prevalence in infants is 1 in 1000 births. Can also occur in elderly (normal pressure hydrocephalus) and after trauma or infection.
treatment_protocol: Imaging → CSF diversion with VP shunt or ETV

epidemiology: Can result from trauma, tumors, abscesses, or degenerative disease. Incidence varies with cause; more common in elderly and cancer patients.
treatment_protocol: Urgent MRI → Steroids → Surgery if compressive lesion

epidemiology: Most common and aggressive primary brain tumor in adults. Incidence: 3.2 per 100,000 annually. Peak age 45–70 years. Male predominance.
treatment_protocol: MRI → Craniotomy/biopsy → Post-op chemoradiotherapy

epidemiology: Most common benign brain tumor. Accounts for ~30% of all intracranial tumors. More common in females (2:1). Peak incidence: 40–60 years.
treatment_protocol: Neuroimaging → Surgical planning → Resect or monitor based on symptoms/size

epidemiology: Accounts for ~5% of all strokes. Incidence: 6–10 per 100,000 per year. Peak age 40–60. Higher in women and smokers.
treatment_protocol: CT → CTA or LP → Coiling or clipping + ICU care

epidemiology: Prevalence ~0.1–0.5%. Often diagnosed in adolescence or early adulthood. Type I is most common and often asymptomatic.
treatment_protocol: MRI confirmation → Surgery if symptomatic or worsening

epidemiology: Affects ~83 per 100,000 adults annually. Peak age 30–50 years. More common in men and those with heavy manual labor.
treatment_protocol: MRI → Trial of conservative care → Surgery if persistent or progressive

epidemiology: Rare but serious condition. Incidence ~1 in 33,000 to 100,000 per year. Commonly due to massive lumbar disc herniation, trauma, or tumors.
treatment_protocol: Immediate MRI → Emergency surgery within 24–48 hrs

epidemiology: Incidence ~0.2–1.2 per 10,000 hospital admissions. Risk increases with immunosuppression and IV drug use. Thoracic spine most commonly affected.
treatment_protocol: MRI + blood work → Start antibiotics → Surgery if neurologic compromise

epidemiology: Prevalence ~1–2% in individuals over 65. Often underdiagnosed. Can mimic neurodegenerative disorders.
treatment_protocol: Imaging + CSF tap test → VP shunt if responsive

epidemiology: Incidence ~1 in 1,000 births globally. More common in low folic acid intake. Most common type: myelomeningocele.
treatment_protocol: Postnatal closure → Shunt if hydrocephalus → Multidisciplinary care

epidemiology: Accounts for ~10–15% of all intracranial tumors. Incidence ~4 per 100,000/year. Most are benign. Prolactinomas are most common subtype.
treatment_protocol: Hormone tests + MRI → Surgery or medical therapy based on type

epidemiology: Affects 1–2% of the population. Most are asymptomatic. Rupture risk increases with size, hypertension, and smoking. More common in women.
treatment_protocol: Identify on imaging → Clip or coil if high rupture risk

epidemiology: Rare; incidence ~1 in 100,000. More common in males. Often diagnosed in teens to early adulthood. Risk of hemorrhage ~2–4%/year.
treatment_protocol: Neuroimaging → Grade AVM → Multimodal treatment based on risk

epidemiology: Prevalence ~0.5% of the population. Can be sporadic or familial. Most remain asymptomatic throughout life.

important: MRI with gradient echo (susceptibility weighted imaging)

definitive: Surgical excision if symptomatic or bleeding

treatment_protocol: MRI confirmation → Conservative vs surgical based on symptoms

epidemiology: Incidence ~4–13 per 100,000/year. More common in women and individuals over 50. Often due to vascular compression of CN V.

timeline.symptom: Brief episodes lasting seconds to minutes

important: MRI brain to rule out compression or MS

treatment_protocol: Trial of medications → Surgery if refractory

epidemiology: Rare congenital or acquired condition. Common in rheumatoid arthritis, connective tissue disorders. Can lead to brainstem compression.
treatment_protocol: Imaging → Surgery if symptomatic or signs of compression

epidemiology: Rare; incidence ~0.5–2 per 100,000 annually. Can be intramedullary (astrocytomas, ependymomas), intradural-extramedullary (meningiomas, schwannomas), or extradural (metastases).
treatment_protocol: MRI → Steroids → Surgery or radiation depending on pathology

epidemiology: More common in children. Associated with spina bifida, lipomas, or dermal sinus tracts. Often diagnosed during evaluation of urinary issues or gait abnormalities.
treatment_protocol: MRI → Urological + neuro exam → Surgery if symptomatic

epidemiology: Common in trauma and metastatic spine disease. Incidence increases with age and osteoporosis. Thoracic and lumbar regions most affected.
treatment_protocol: CT/MRI → Decompression + fixation if unstable or neurological signs

epidemiology: Most common intracranial tumors in adults. Occur in 20–40% of cancer patients. Common primaries: lung, breast, melanoma, kidney, colon.
treatment_protocol: MRI → Resect solitary lesion or radiosurgery → Adjuvant therapy

epidemiology: Benign suprasellar tumor; bimodal age distribution (children 5–14 and adults 50–74). Incidence: ~0.5–2 per million/year.
treatment_protocol: MRI → Surgery → Adjuvant radiation if needed

epidemiology: Benign cyst usually in third ventricle. Rare, but can cause acute hydrocephalus and death. Typically presents in adults 20–50 years old.

timeline.symptom: Drop attacks or sudden loss of consciousness

treatment_protocol: MRI/CT → Surgery if symptomatic or obstructive

epidemiology: A neural tube defect that is less common than myelomeningocele. Incidence ~1 per 10,000 births. Typically diagnosed at birth.
treatment_protocol: Surgical repair soon after birth to prevent complications

epidemiology: Most severe form of spina bifida. Incidence ~1–2 per 1,000 births. Common in regions with low folate intake.

timeline.symptom: Visible protruding sac with neural tissue

treatment_protocol: Surgical closure within 48 hours of birth → Shunt placement as needed

epidemiology: Congenital brain malformation. Incidence ~1 per 30,000 births. Commonly associated with hydrocephalus and chromosomal anomalies.
treatment_protocol: MRI diagnosis → Shunt for hydrocephalus → Monitor development

epidemiology: Occurs in 2% of head trauma cases. Most common in young males. Often caused by temporal bone fracture tearing middle meningeal artery.

emergency_markers: Loss of consciousness + CT showing biconvex hematoma

treatment_protocol: CT diagnosis → Urgent surgical evacuation

epidemiology: Common in high-impact head trauma. Basilar fractures ~4% of severe head injuries. Depressed fractures more frequent in assault or falls.
treatment_protocol: CT confirmation → Surgery if depressed or leaking

epidemiology: Rare but serious. Incidence: 0.3–1.3 per 100,000/year. Common in immunocompromised, patients with congenital heart disease, or contiguous infection.
treatment_protocol: MRI → Empirical antibiotics → Surgery if large or no response

epidemiology: Most common cause of spinal cord dysfunction in adults over 55. Degenerative narrowing of the spinal canal due to osteophytes and disc herniation.

definitive: Decompressive laminectomy or anterior cervical discectomy and fusion (ACDF)

treatment_protocol: MRI → Surgical decompression in moderate/severe or progressive cases

epidemiology: Most common in obese women of childbearing age. Incidence ~1–3 per 100,000/year. Also called pseudotumor cerebri.
treatment_protocol: MRI/MRV → LP → Medical therapy → Shunt if vision threatened

epidemiology: Rare but increasingly recognized. Incidence ~0.2–2 per 10,000 hospital admissions. Most common organism: Staphylococcus aureus.
treatment_protocol: MRI → Start antibiotics → Surgery if deficit or abscess confirmed

epidemiology: Rare, accounting for <1% of brain tumors. More common in children and young adults. Germ cell tumors are the most frequent subtype.
treatment_protocol: MRI → Tumor markers → Surgery ± RT/CT

epidemiology: Mostly affects children (median age 6–10). Diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG) is the most lethal form. Accounts for ~10–20% of pediatric CNS tumors.
treatment_protocol: MRI → Radiotherapy (no resection for DIPG) → Consider trials

epidemiology: Affects 1–2% of the population annually. Peak incidence in 30–50 years. Most common at L4-L5 and L5-S1 levels.
treatment_protocol: MRI → Conservative management → Surgery if no improvement or emergency signs

epidemiology: Autosomal dominant. Incidence ~1 in 3,000. Associated with optic gliomas, plexiform neurofibromas, and learning disabilities.
treatment_protocol: Genetic diagnosis → Periodic imaging → Surgery/chemo as indicated

epidemiology: Autosomal dominant. Incidence ~1 in 25,000. Characterized by bilateral vestibular schwannomas and spinal tumors.

important: MRI brain and spine with contrast

treatment_protocol: MRI → Audiometry → Surgery or radiosurgery as needed

epidemiology: Accounts for ~25–45% of primary spinal cord tumors. Most common in middle-aged women. Typically intradural and extramedullary.
treatment_protocol: MRI → Surgical resection → Post-op rehab

epidemiology: Rare malignant tumor from notochord remnants. Incidence ~0.1 per 100,000. Most common at skull base (clivus) and sacrum.
treatment_protocol: Imaging → Biopsy → Surgery + Proton RT

epidemiology: Benign cystic lesion, rare. Represents ~0.5–1% of intracranial tumors. Typically presents in young adults.
treatment_protocol: MRI → Surgery to prevent hydrocephalus/death

epidemiology: Rare vascular lesion. Estimated prevalence ~3–10 per 100,000. Most common in thoracolumbar region. Male > female.
treatment_protocol: MRI → Angiography → Embolization or Surgery
